content: The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, amends the existing program to focus on coordination and information exchange among Federal agencies for the implementation of dam safety guidelines. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, introduces amendments to improve dam safety in the United States. These include changes to Section 8 regarding the preparation of a strategic plan, establishment of goals and priorities, cooperation with governmental entities, and development of technical assistance materials for dam security. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 introduces amendments to improve dam safety in the United States, including developing technical assistance materials and coordinating national efforts to enhance dam safety. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 is amended to provide assistance for States in establishing, maintaining, and improving dam safety programs. The term "contract" is replaced with "agreement" in paragraph (3). The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 is amended to establish a Board to monitor dam safety in the United States and advise on national dam safety policy. Voting membership is clarified with 11 voting members and certain subparagraphs are revised. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 is amended to establish a Board with 11 voting members, including representatives from State dam safety officials and the private sector. Nonvoting members may include representatives from Federal or State agencies, National Laboratories of the Department of Energy, and dam safety experts as needed. The Board's duties include promoting effective dam safety programs and policies. The Board established under the Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 encourages effective dam safety programs and policies, coordinates information exchange among Federal and State agencies, and may establish work groups to assist in achieving its goals. The Board established under the Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 may establish work groups consisting of Board members and other selected individuals. Travel expenses for Board members representing Federal agencies are reimbursed by their agency, while other members are reimbursed if funds are available in advance. The Board, member representing a State agency, member from the private sector, and work group members will be reimbursed for travel expenses by FEMA, including per diem, while performing services for the Board. SEC. 4 amends Section 9(a) to include cooperation with the Board, develop and support information resources systems for dam safety, and guide public policy for dam safety engineering. SEC. 5 redesignates sections and adds a new section for dam safety training. SEC. 10. DAM SAFETY TRAINING. The Director will provide training for State dam safety staff and inspectors upon request from States with or planning a dam safety program. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Section 11 is amended by removing subsection (a) and everything following it until "(b) Biennial Reports.--". SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 13 of the Act is amended to increase annual amounts to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Allocation changes include updating references to sections and removing specific assistance needs. Research funding is set at $1,500,000 for each fiscal year 2003 through 2006 for section 9 activities. Authorized funding for dam safety training under section 10 is set at $500,000 annually for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Additionally, $600,000 per year is allocated for FEMA staff employment to support sections 8 through 10.
